And that meant Wellpinit, the smaller, Indian town, was also a place of mystery.<br /><br /> \"Okay, so it\'s like each of these books is a mystery. Every book is a mystery. And if you read all of the books ever written, it\'s like you\'ve read one giant mystery. And no matter how much you learn, you keep on learning so much more you need to learn. \"<br /><br />\"Yes, yes, yes, yes,\" Gordy said. \"Now doesn\'t that give you a boner? \"<br /><br /> \"I am rock hard, \" I said.&rdquo;
author: Sherman Alexie

quote: &ldquo;Censorship of anything, at any time, in any place, on whatever pretense, has always been and always will be the last resort of the boob and the bigot.&rdquo;
author: Eugene O'Neill

quote: &ldquo;But her grandmother had never suggested she could think the same of Scarlet. You\'ll be fine, she always said, after a skinned knee, after a broken arm, after her first youthfull heartbreak. You\'ll be fine, because you\'re strong, like me.&rdquo;
author: Marissa Meyer

quote: &ldquo;Books must be treated with respect, we feel that in our bones, because words have power. Bring enough words together they can bend space and time.&rdquo;
author: Terry Pratchett

quote: &ldquo;But you love books, then,” Aunt Queen was saying. I had to listen.<br /><br />\"Oh, yes,” Lestat said. \"Sometimes they are the only thing that keeps me alive.”<br /><br />\"What a strange thing to say at your age,” she laughed.<br /><br />\"No, but one can feel desperate at any age, don\'t you think? The young are eternally desperate,” he said frankly. \"And books, they offer one hope -- that a whole universe might open up from between the covers, and falling into that new universe, one is saved.&rdquo;
author: Anne Rice

quote: &ldquo;The moon will guide you through the night with her brightness, but she will always dwell in the darkness, in order to be seen.&rdquo;
author: Shannon L. Alder

quote: &ldquo;Dreams, books, are each a world; and books, we know,<br />Are a substantial world, both pure and good:<br />Round these, with tendrils strong as flesh and blood,<br />Our pastime and our happiness will grow.&rdquo;
author: William Wordsworth

quote: &ldquo;We become the books we read.&rdquo;
author: Matthew Kelly

quote: &ldquo;Imagination is what you do with your inspiration.&rdquo;
author: Violet Haberdasher

quote: &ldquo;I had lines inside me, a string of guiding lights. I had language. Fiction and poetry are doses, medicines. What they heal is the rupture reality makes on the imagination. I had been damaged, and a very important part of me had been destroyed - that was my reality, the facts of my life. But on the other side of the facts was who I could be, how I could feel. And as long as I had words for that, images for that, stories for that, then I wasn\'t lost.&rdquo;
author: Jeanette Winterson

quote: &ldquo;Just as music is noise that makes sense, a painting is colour that makes sense, so a story is life that makes sense.&rdquo;
author: Yann Martel

quote: &ldquo;Woe be to him that reads but one book.&rdquo;
author: George Herbert

quote: &ldquo;Reading was not a fallback position for her but an ideal state of being.&rdquo;
author: Laura Lippman

quote: &ldquo;When I want to read a novel, I write one.&rdquo;
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: &ldquo;My last refuge, my books: simple pleasures, like finding wild onions by the side of a road, or requited love.&rdquo;
author: Tracy Letts

quote: &ldquo;Tis the good reader that makes the good book; in every book he finds passages which seem confidences or asides hidden from all else and unmistakenly meant for his ear; the profit of books is according to the sensibility of the reader; the profoundest thought or passion sleeps as in a mine, until it is discovered by an equal mind and heart.&rdquo;
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: &ldquo;I read in self-defense.&rdquo;
author: Woody Allen

quote: &ldquo;The best books...<br /><br />The best books of men are soon exhausted--<br />they are cisterns, and not springing fountains.<br />You enjoy them very much at the first acquaintance,<br />and you think you could hear them a hundred times over-<br />but you could not- you soon find them wearisome.<br />Very speedily a man eats too much honey:<br />even children at length are cloyed with sweets.<br /><br />All human books grow stale after a time-<br />but with the Word of God the desire to study it increases,<br />while the more you know of it the less you think you know.<br /><br />The Book grows upon you: as you dive into its depths<br />you have a fuller perception of the infinity which remains<br />to be explored. You are still sighing to enjoy more of that<br />which it is your bliss to taste.&rdquo;
author: Charles Haddon Spurgeon

quote: &ldquo;great books are the ones we need&rdquo;
author: Charles Bukowski

quote: &ldquo;A book is an arrangement of twenty-six phonetic symbols, ten numerals, and about eight punctuation marks, and people can cast their eyes over these and envision the eruption of Mount Vesuvius or the Battle of Waterloo.&rdquo;
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.

quote: &ldquo;Books swept me away, this way and that, one after the other; I made endless vows according to their lights for I believed them.&rdquo;
author: Annie Dillard

quote: &ldquo;Do you arrange your books alphabetically? (I hope not.)&rdquo;
author: Mary Ann Shaffer

quote: &ldquo;Book burnings. Always the forerunners. Heralds of the stake, the ovens, the mass graves.&rdquo;
author: Geraldine Brooks

quote: &ldquo;In a library, no empty shelf remains empty for long.&rdquo;
author: Alberto Manguel

quote: &ldquo;This must be what an addict feels like, I think, <br />trying to fight the pull of one last, quick read. My fingers itch toward the binding, and finally, with a sigh of regret, I just grab the book and open it, hungrily reading the story.&rdquo;
author: Jodi Picoult

quote: &ldquo;The wise man reads both books and life itself.&rdquo;
author: Lin Yutang

quote: &ldquo;However much you study, you cannot know without action. <br />A donkey laden with books is neither an intellectual nor a wise man. <br />Empty of essence, what learning has he whether upon him is firewood or book?&rdquo;
author: Saadi

quote: &ldquo;Well, it seems to me that there are books that tell stories, and then there are books that tell truths... The first kind, they show you life like you want it to be. With villains getting what they deserve and the hero seeing what a fool he\'s been and marrying the heroine and happy endings and all that... But the second kind, they show you life more like it is... The first kind makes you cheerful and contented, but the second kind shakes you up.&rdquo;
author: Jennifer Donnelly

quote: &ldquo;A good book is always on tap; it may be decanted and drunk a hundred times, and it is still there for further imbibement. &rdquo;
author: Holbrook Jackson

quote: &ldquo;One of the poets, whose name I cannot recall, has a passage, which I am unable at the moment to remember, in one of his works, which for the time being has slipped my mind, which hits off admirably this age-old situation.&rdquo;
author: P.G. Wodehouse

quote: &ldquo;The books that everybody admires are those that nobody reads.&rdquo;
author: Anatole France

quote: &ldquo;Old words are reborn with new faces.&rdquo;
author: Criss Jami

quote: &ldquo;But we do need a breather. We do need knowledge. And perhaps in a thousand years we might pick smaller cliffs to jump off. The books are to remind us what asses and fools we are. They\'re Caesar\'s praetorian guard, whispering as the parade roars down the avenue, ‘Remember, Caesar, thou art mortal.\' Most of us can\'t rush around, talk to everyone, know all the cities of the world, we haven\'t time, money or that many friends. The things you\'re looking for, Montag, are in the world, but the only way the average chap will ever see ninety-nine per cent of them is in a book.&rdquo;
author: Ray Bradbury

quote: &ldquo;[W]hat I like best is staying home and reading. Being rich is not about how many homes you own. It\'s the freedom to pick up any book you want without looking at the price and wondering whether you can afford it.&rdquo;
author: John Waters

quote: &ldquo;He fed his spirit with the bread of books&rdquo;
author: Edwin Markham

quote: &ldquo;The book was in her lap; she had read no further. The power to change one\'s life comes from a paragraph, a lone remark. The lines that penetrate us are slender, like the flukes that live in river water and enter the bodies of swimmers. She was excited, filled with strength. The polished sentences had arrived, it seemed, like so many other things, at just the right time. How can we imagine what our lives should be without the illumination of the lives of others?&rdquo;
author: James Salter

quote: &ldquo;Khalil, I\'ll never forget.<br />I\'ll never give up.<br />I\'ll never be quiet.<br />I promise.&rdquo;
author: Angie Thomas

quote: &ldquo;I\'ve forgotten most of what I\'ve read and, frankly, it never seemed very important to me or to the world.&rdquo;
author: Leonard Cohen

quote: &ldquo;Books remember all the things you cannot contain.&rdquo;
author: Elizabeth McCracken

quote: &ldquo;Computers don\'t kill books; people do.&rdquo;
author: Douglas Rushkoff

quote: &ldquo;For all the books in his possession, he still failed to read the stories written plain as day in the faces of the people around him.&rdquo;
author: Emma Donoghue

quote: &ldquo;A tough life needs a tough language-and that is what poetry is. That is what literature offers-a language powerful enough to say how it is.&rdquo;
author: Jeanette Winterson

quote: &ldquo;When confronted with a birthday in a week I will remember that a book can be a really good present, too.&rdquo;
author: Stephanie Pearl-McPhee

quote: &ldquo;Literature is the real life of imaginary people.&rdquo;
author: Stefanos Livos

quote: &ldquo;There\'s no mistaking a real book when one meets it. It is like falling in love.&rdquo;
author: Christopher  Morley

quote: &ldquo;A wonderful thing about a book, in contrast to a computer screen, is that you can take it to bed with you.&rdquo;
author: Daniel J. Boorstin

quote: &ldquo;In Tereza\'s eyes, books were the emblems of a secret brotherhood. For she had but a single weapon against the world of crudity surrounding her: the novels. She had read any number of them, from Fielding to Thomas Mann. They not only offered the possibility of an imaginary escape from a life she found unsatisfying; they also had a meaning for her as physical objects: she loved to walk down the street with a book under her arm. It had the same significance for her as an elegant cane from the dandy a century ago. It differentiated her from others.&rdquo;
author: Milan Kundera

quote: &ldquo;Fenworth owned a world-famous library. More rooms held books than beds. Pillows stuffed in niches and comfortable chairs scattered throughout each room offered abundant paces to curl up and read.&rdquo;
author: Donita K. Paul

quote: &ldquo;Libraries are not made; they grow. Good as it is to inherit a library, it is better to collect one.&rdquo;
author: Augustine Birrell

quote: &ldquo;Learning to decipher words had only added to the pleasures of holding spines and turning pages, measuring the journey to the end with a thumb-riffle, poring over frontispieces. Books! Opening with a crackle of old glue, releasing perfume; closing with a solid thump.&rdquo;
author: John Crowley

quote: &ldquo;There is this idea that you either read to escape or you read to find yourself. I don\'t really see the difference. We find ourselves through the process of escaping.&rdquo;
author: Matt Haig

quote: &ldquo;I do not believe that all books will or should migrate onto screens: as Douglas Adams once pointed out to me, more than 20 years before the Kindle showed up, a physical book is like a shark. Sharks are old: there were sharks in the ocean before the dinosaurs. And the reason there are still sharks around is that sharks are better at being sharks than anything else is. Physical books are tough, hard to destroy, bath-resistant, solar-operated, feel good in your hand: they are good at being books, and there wil always be a place for them.&rdquo;
author: Neil Gaiman

quote: &ldquo;The irritating question they ask us -- us being writers -- is: \"Where do you get your ideas?\"<br />And the answer is: Confluence. Things come together. The right ingredients and suddenly: <i>Abracadabra!</i>&rdquo;
author: Neil Gaiman

quote: &ldquo;The love of learning, the sequestered nooks,<br />And all the sweet serenity of books&rdquo;
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: &ldquo;[D]on\'t ever apologise to an author for buying something in paperback, or taking it out from a library (that\'s what they\'re there for. <i>Use</i> your library). Don\'t apologise to <i>this</i> author for buying books second hand, or getting them from bookcrossing or borrowing a friend\'s copy. What\'s important to me is that people read the books and enjoy them, and that, at some point in there, the book was bought by someone. And that people who like things, tell other people. The most important thing is that people <i>read</i>...&rdquo;
author: Neil Gaiman

quote: &ldquo;It doesn\'t matter. I have books, new books, and I can bear anything as long as there are books.&rdquo;
author: Jo Walton

quote: &ldquo;I kept always two books in my pocket, one to read, one to write in.&rdquo;
author: Robert Louis Stevenson

quote: &ldquo;Words dazzle and deceive because they are mimed by the face. But black words on a white page are the soul laid bare.&rdquo;
author: Guy de Maupassant

quote: &ldquo;What a blessing it is to love books as I love them;- to be able to converse with the dead, and to live amidst the unreal!&rdquo;
author: Thomas Babington Macaulay

quote: &ldquo;If you have enough book space, I don\'t want to talk to you.&rdquo;
author: Terry Pratchett

quote: &ldquo;Once you have read a book you care about, some part of it is always with you.&rdquo;
author: Louis L'Amour

quote: &ldquo;Books serve to show a man that those original thoughts of his aren\'t very new after all.&rdquo;
author: Abraham Lincoln

quote: &ldquo;Books are no more threatened by Kindle than stairs by elevators.&rdquo;
author: Stephen Fry

quote: &ldquo;He was the crazy one who had painted himself black and defeated the world.<br /><br />She was the book thief without the words.<br /><br />Trust me, though, the words were on their way, and when they arrived, Liesel would hold them in her hands like the clouds, and she would wring them out like rain.&rdquo;
author: Markus Zusak

quote: &ldquo;We don\'t need a list of rights and wrongs, tables of dos and don\'ts: we need books, time, and silence. <i>Thou shalt not</i> is soon forgotten, but <i>Once upon a time</i> lasts forever.&rdquo;
author: Philip Pullman

quote: &ldquo;Reading is like thinking, like praying, like talking to a friend, like expressing your ideas, like listening to other people\'s ideas, like listening to music, like looking at the view, like taking a walk on the beach.&rdquo;
author: Roberto Bolaño

quote: &ldquo;Five exclamation marks, the sure sign of an insane mind.&rdquo;
author: Terry Pratchett

quote: &ldquo;Literature is a luxury; fiction is a necessity.&rdquo;
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: &ldquo;There must be something in books, something we can\'t imagine, to make a woman stay in a burning house; there must be something there. You don\'t stay for nothing.&rdquo;
author: Ray Bradbury

quote: &ldquo;The worst thing about new books is that they keep us from reading the old ones.&rdquo;
author: Joseph Joubert

quote: &ldquo;Be awesome! Be a book nut!&rdquo;
author: Dr. Seuss

quote: &ldquo;Book collecting is an obsession, an occupation, a disease, an addiction, a fascination, an absurdity, a fate. It is not a hobby. Those who do it must do it. Those who do not do it, think of it as a cousin of stamp collecting, a sister of the trophy cabinet, bastard of a sound bank account and a weak mind.&rdquo;
author: Jeanette Winterson

quote: &ldquo;Books: a beautifully browsable invention that needs no electricity and exists in a readable form no matter what happens.&rdquo;
author: Nicholson Baker

quote: &ldquo;I am awfully greedy; I want everything from life. I want to be a woman and to be a man, to have many friends and to have loneliness, to work much and write good books, to travel and enjoy myself, to be selfish and to be unselfish… You see, it is difficult to get all which I want. And then when I do not succeed I get mad with anger.&rdquo;
author: Simone de Beauvoir

quote: &ldquo;My alma mater was books, a good library.... I could spend the rest of my life reading, just satisfying my curiosity.&rdquo;
author: Malcolm X

quote: &ldquo;Everything in the world exists in order to end up as a book.&rdquo;
author: Stéphane Mallarmé

quote: &ldquo;Even in literature and art, no man who bothers about originality will ever be original: whereas if you simply try to tell the truth (without caring twopence how often it has been told before) you will, nine times out of ten, become original without ever having noticed it.&rdquo;
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: &ldquo;There is more treasure in books than in all the pirates\' loot on Treasure Island and best of all, you can enjoy these riches every day of your life.&rdquo;
author: Walt Disney Company

quote: &ldquo;We are of opinion that instead of letting books grow moldy behind an iron grating, far from the vulgar gaze, it is better to let them wear out by being read.&rdquo;
author: Jules Verne

quote: &ldquo;We can ignore reality, but we cannot ignore the consequences of ignoring reality.&rdquo;
author: Ayn Rand

quote: &ldquo;People talk about books that write themselves, and it\'s a lie. Books don\'t write themselves. It takes thought and research and backache and notes and more time and more work than you\'d believe.&rdquo;
author: Neil Gaiman

quote: &ldquo;A book is much more than a delivery vehicle for its contents.&rdquo;
author: Allison Hoover Bartlett

quote: &ldquo;You never forget the books you loved as a kid. You never forget the poems you memorized, the first book you read until the cover fell off, the book you read hidden from your mother. What an honor to hold hands with a child\'s imagination in this way.&rdquo;
author: Meg Medina

quote: &ldquo;Let the readers do some of the work themselves&rdquo;
author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

quote: &ldquo;He couldn\'t seem to get his teeth into anything. Except books. The things in books was darn near more real to him than the things breathing and eating.&rdquo;
author: Ken Kesey

quote: &ldquo;When you buy a jacket, it\'s important the pockets are big enough for a paperback!&rdquo;
author: Daniel Pennac

quote: &ldquo;Books can be immensely powerful. The ideas in them can change the way people think. Yet it was the Nazis and Stalin\'s officers who committed terrible crimes, and not Mein Kampf or the Communist Manifesto - and of course, the Manifesto contained many key ideas that are still relevant and important today, long after Stalin has gone. There is a crucial distinction between the book and its effect - it\'s crucial because if you talk about a book being harmful rather than its effect you begin to legitimise censorship. Abhorrent ideas need to be challenged by better ones, not banned.&rdquo;
author: John Farndon

quote: &ldquo;The portraits, of more historical than artistic interest, had gone; and tapestry, full of the blue and bronze of peacocks, fell over the doors, and shut out all history and activity untouched with beauty and peace; and now when I looked at my Crevelli and pondered on the rose in the hand of the Virgin, wherein the form was so delicate and precise that it seemed more like a thought than a flower, or at the grey dawn and rapturous faces of my Francesca, I knew all a Christian\'s ecstasy without his slavery to rule and custom; when I pondered over the antique bronze gods and goddesses, which I had mortgaged my house to buy, I had all a pagan\'s delight in various beauty and without his terror at sleepless destiny and his labour with many sacrifices; and I had only to go to my bookshelf, where every book was bound in leather, stamped with intricate ornament, and of a carefully chosen colour: Shakespeare in the orange of the glory of the world, Dante in the dull red of his anger, Milton in the blue grey of his formal calm; and I could experience what I would of human passions without their bitterness and without satiety. I had gathered about me all gods because I believed in none, and experienced every pleasure because I gave myself to none, but held myself apart, individual, indissoluble, a mirror of polished steel: I looked in the triumph of this imagination at the birds of Hera, glowing in the firelight as though they were wrought of jewels; and to my mind, for which symbolism was a necessity, they seemed the doorkeepers of my world, shutting out all that was not of as affluent a beauty as their own; and for a moment I thought as I had thought in so many other moments, that it was possible to rob life of every bitterness except the bitterness of death; and then a thought which had followed this thought, time after time, filled me with a passionate sorrow.&rdquo;
author: W.B. Yeats

quote: &ldquo;...this blessing of loneliness was not really loneliness. Real loneliness was something unendurable. What one wanted when exhausted by the noise and impact of physical bodies was not no people but disembodied people; all those denizens of beloved books who could be taken to one\'s heart and put away again, in silence, and with no hurt feelings.&rdquo;
author: Elizabeth Goudge

quote: &ldquo;Write It, Work It, Publish&rdquo;
author: Cherry-Ann Carew

quote: &ldquo;My depth of purse is not so great<br />Nor yet my bibliophilic greed,<br />That merely buying doth elate:<br />The books I buy I like to read:<br />Still e\'en when dawdling in a mead,<br />Beneath a cloudless summer sky,<br />By bank of Thames, or Tyne, or Tweed,<br />The books I read - I like to buy.&rdquo;
author: A. Edward Newton

quote: &ldquo;It\'s a symbiotic process, writing. What I am makes the books-not part of me, all of me-and then the books themselves inform the sense of what I am. So the more I can be, the better the books will be.&rdquo;
author: Jeanette Winterson

quote: &ldquo;Pienso que en la vida de cada uno de nosotros existe un libro similar, que de pequeños no nos limitamos simplemente a leer, sino que inspeccionamos y rebuscamos en cada uno de sus rincones como si de una habitación se tratara. Un libro así, rebuscado como una habitación, escrutado o interrogado como una cara en cada rasgo y arruga, nunca podremos juzgarlo como se juzga un libro, porque para nosotros ha abandonado la zona de los libros y ha pasado a vivir a la zona de la memoria y de los afectos.&rdquo;
author: Natalia Ginzburg

quote: &ldquo;…secondhand bookstores have pilgrims. The words out of print are a call to arms for those who seek a Holy Grail made of paper and ink.&rdquo;
author: Kathleen Tessaro

quote: &ldquo;It would be curious to discover who it is to whom one writes in a diary. Possibly to some mysterious personification of one\'s own identity.&rdquo;
author: Beatrice Potter Webb

quote: &ldquo;Initiative is doing the right thing without being told.&rdquo;
author: Victor Hugo

quote: &ldquo;Brrr, who had never admired books particularly...didn\'t remember that a mere book might reek of sex, possibility, fecundity. Yet a book has a ripe furrow and a yielding spine, he thought, and the nuances to be teased from its pages are nearly infinite in their variety and coquettish appeal. And what new life can emerge from a book. Any book, maybe.&rdquo;
author: Gregory Maguire

quote: &ldquo;I asked her what a true story was because I thought that all stories were made up. She said a true story was called fact, and a made-up story was called ficton. Auntie May said a made-up story is a bit like telling lies, only the people who read them knew that already and so it didn\'t matter&rdquo;
author: Rebecca Lloyd

quote: &ldquo;Read him slowly, dear girl, you must read Kipling slowly. Watch carefully where the commas fall so you can discover the natural pauses. He is a writer who used pen and ink. He looked up from the page a lot, I believe, stared through his window and listened to birds, as most writers who are alone do. Some do not know the names of birds, though he did. Your eye is too quick and North American. Think about the speed of his pen. What an appalling, barnacled old first paragraph it is otherwise.&rdquo;
author: Michael Ondaatje

quote: &ldquo;No matter how many compromises were made along the way, no matter what happens in the future, a book is a thing to behold.&rdquo;
author: Betsy Lerner

quote: &ldquo;Oscar was raised to believe that if he stayed in his room reading about made up worlds it meant he didn\'t appreciate the life he had, the possessions his parents had worked hard for, like the TV and the video and the newly turfed back garden.&rdquo;
author: Benjamin Wood

quote: &ldquo;Somewhere there must be women reading books,<br />and talking of chicken rissoles to their cooks …<br /><br />(from,‘Somewhere in England\')&rdquo;
author: Virginia Graham

quote: &ldquo;She fancied herself superiour to her surroundings: surely there were higher things to live for. Yet the ugliness of this room was but a part of what she felt to be the dreariness of all life outside of books.&rdquo;
author: Goodreads on Facebook

quote: &ldquo;There was an abyss. And books contained magical incantations to raise what was hidden there, all the great mysteries.&rdquo;
author: Stephen King

quote: &ldquo;All books are good,\' he said...<br />\'They weren\'t bad books,\' Phin countered patiently. \'They were books that you didn\'t enjoy. It\'s not the same thing at all. The only bad books are books that are so badly written that no one will publish them. Any book that has been published is going to be a \'good book\' for someone.\'<br />I nodded. I couldn\'t fault his logic.&rdquo;
author: Lisa Jewell

quote: &ldquo;The problem is, we bring ourselves to the pages. Our whole selves. Every single darkness. Every single light. Every single passion. Every single hurt. We read with all the layers that make us who we are acting as filters. We read with all that our eyes have seen and all our hearts have felt since birth. With that much density making up humanity, it can\'t be up to us to make sure people don\'t misunderstand a book. And it can\'t be up to books to make sure people don\'t kill themselves or hate someone, or even love someone. Or even decide to be president. What we do, before and after we read, is our choice. And that choice is freedom.&rdquo;
author: Dave Connis

quote: &ldquo;In films, we are voyeurs, but in novels, we have the experience of being someone else: knowing another person\'s soul from the inside. No other art form does that. And this is why sometimes, when we put down a book, we find ourselves slightly altered as human beings. Novels change us from within.&rdquo;
author: Donna Tartt

quote: &ldquo;And long gone are the days when a paperback meant a Penguin, pure and simple, let alone when a paperback publisher could confidently market a product with no image at all on the cover - just the title and the author\'s name, emphatically lettered. Beautiful.&rdquo;
author: Penelope Lively

quote: &ldquo;Elk boek, elke band die je ziet, is bezield. Bezield door degene die het schreef, bezield door degenen die het lazen en doorleefden en ervan droomden. Telkens als een boek in andere handen overgaat, telkens als iemand zijn blik over de bladzijden laat gaan, groeit zijn geest en wordt sterk.&rdquo;
author: Carlos Ruiz Zafón

quote: &ldquo;A newspaper man I know, who was stationed in London during the war, says tourists go to England with preconceived notions, so they always find exactly what they go looking for. I told him I\'d go looking for the England of English literature, and he said: \"Then it\'s there.&rdquo;
author: Helene Hanff

quote: &ldquo;Because there was an abyss. And books contained magical incantations to raise what was hidden there, all the great mysteries. For Luke, those mysteries mattered. Someday in the future, he might write books of his own. But here the only future was Back Half. Here, the future of existence was, \'What good would it do?&rdquo;
author: Stephen King

quote: &ldquo;I know of no pleasure like that of books, yet I read very little. Books are the entryway to dreams, but people at ease in life don\'t need such introductions to enter into conversation with dreams. I could never read a book and give myself over to it; always, with each step, the commentary of my intellect or my imagination interrupts the narrative sequence. After some minutes I am the one who writes and the writing is nowhere to be seen.&rdquo;
author: Fernando Pessoa

quote: &ldquo;I, for one, never can have too many books; nor can my books cover too many subjects. I may never read them all, but they are always there, and I never know what strange coast I am going to pick up at any time in sailing the world of knowledge.&rdquo;
author: Jack London

quote: &ldquo;pregnant belly of<br />sunlight, bouncing<br />over an open book&rdquo;
author: Bremer Acosta

quote: &ldquo;It\'s terrible, … for us to have been so scared to be seen with books we have every right to read.&rdquo;
author: Nancy Garden

quote: &ldquo;The lonely fill up their lives with books. I don\'t live in nature. I don\'t live in culture. I don\'t live in my relationships. I live in books. What good can all the books of the world be, penned by the loneliest men who ever lived?&rdquo;
author: Sheila Heti

quote: &ldquo;We were very much a reading family, but we were a borrow-a-book-from-the-library family more than a bookshelves-full-of-books family. My parents valued books, but the grew up in the Depression, aware of the quicksilver nature of money, and they learned the hard way that you shouldn\'t buy what you could borrow. Because of that frugality, or perhaps independent of it, they also believed that you read a book for the experience of reading it.&rdquo;
author: Susan Orlean

quote: &ldquo;We were very much a reading family, but we were a borrow-a-book-from-the-library family more than a bookshelves-full-of-books family. My parents valued books, but they grew up in the Depression, aware of the quicksilver nature of money, and they learned the hard way that you shouldn\'t buy what you could borrow. Because of that frugality, or perhaps independent of it, they also believed that you read a book for the experience of reading it.&rdquo;
author: Susan Orlean

quote: &ldquo;At the time, the library\'s fire prevention consisted of smoke detectors and handheld fire extinguishers. There were no sprinklers. The American Library Association, known informally as the ALA, always advised against sprinklers, because water damage was even worse for books than fire damage.&rdquo;
author: Susan Orlean

quote: &ldquo;Overnight, the city managed to procure thousands of cardboard boxes, fifteen hundred hard hats, a few thousand rolls of packing tape, and the services of Eric Lundquist, a mechanical engineer and former popcorn distributor who had reinvented himself as a expert in drying out wet things. The notion of putting the books in with groceries didn\'t faze Lundquist, since he\'d freeze-dried his first salvaged books alongside a summer\'s worth of peas and carrots from his garden.&rdquo;
author: Susan Orlean

quote: &ldquo;With Lundquist directing, the volunteers worked for the next three days around the clock. Most were strangers to each other, drawn together unexpectedly, and worked together for hours, diligently and peacefully. The formed a human chain, passing the books hand over hand from one person the the next, through the smoky building and out the door. It was as if, in the urgent moment, the people of Los Angeles formed a living library. They created, for that short time, a system to protect and pass along shared knowledge, to save what we know for each other, which is what libraries do everyday.&rdquo;
author: Susan Orlean

quote: &ldquo;With Lundquist directing, the volunteers worked for the next three days around the clock. Most were strangers to each other, drawn together unexpectedly, and worked together for hours, diligently and peacefully. The formed a human chain, passing the books hand over hand from one person the the next, through the smoky building and out the door. It was as if, in this urgent moment, the people of Los Angeles formed a living library. They created, for that short time, a system to protect and pass along shared knowledge, to save what we know for each other, which is what libraries do everyday.&rdquo;
author: Susan Orlean

quote: &ldquo;A house that has books has hope.&rdquo;
author: Nitya Prakash

quote: &ldquo;Publishing short quotes surpassed the fame of being an author of books.&rdquo;
author: Steven Magee

quote: &ldquo;Read, sweet, how others strove,<br />Till we are stouter;<br />What they renounced,<br />Till we are less afraid;<br />How many times they bore<br />The faithful witness,<br />Till we are helped,<br />As if a kingdom cared!<br /><br />Read then of faith<br />That shone above the fagot;<br />Clear strains of hymn<br />The river could not drown;<br />Brave names of men<br />And celestial women,<br />Passed out of record<br />Into renown!&rdquo;
author: Emily Dickinson

quote: &ldquo;i hope i sell some books soonest&rdquo;
author: Stephen O'Shea

quote: &ldquo;It is only a novel... or, in short, only some work in which the greatest powers of the mind are displayed, in which the most thorough knowledge of human nature, the happiest delineation of its varieties, the liveliest effusions of wit and humour, are conveyed to the world in the best-chosen language&rdquo;
author: Jane Austen

quote: &ldquo;Literature is news that stays news.&rdquo;
author: Ezra Pound

quote: &ldquo;The world was a terrible place, cruel, pitiless, dark as a bad dream. Not a good place to live. Only in books could you find pity, comfort, happiness - and love. Books loved anyone who opened them, they gave you security and friendship and didn\'t ask anything in return; they never went away, never, not even when you treated them badly.&rdquo;
author: Cornelia Funke

quote: &ldquo;Take no heed of her.... She reads a lot of books.&rdquo;
author: Jasper Fforde

quote: &ldquo;I went away in my head, into a book. That was where I went whenever real life was too hard or too inflexible.&rdquo;
author: Neil Gaiman

quote: &ldquo;The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us.&rdquo;
author: Ray Bradbury

quote: &ldquo;The books transported her into new worlds and introduced her to amazing people who lived exciting lives. She went on olden-day sailing ships with Joseph Conrad. She went to Africa with Ernest Hemingway and to India with Rudyard Kipling. She travelled all over the world while sitting in her little room in an English village.&rdquo;
author: Roald Dahl

quote: &ldquo;There is no such thing as a moral or an immoral book.<br />Books are well written, or badly written. That is all.&rdquo;
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: &ldquo;Which of us has not felt that the character we are reading in the printed page is more real than the person standing beside us?&rdquo;
author: Cornelia Funke

quote: &ldquo;A book is a garden, an orchard, a storehouse, a party, a company by the way, a counselor, a multitude of counselors.&rdquo;
author: Charles Baudelaire

quote: &ldquo;Everybody does have a book in them, but in most cases that\'s where it should stay.&rdquo;
author: Christopher Hitchens

quote: &ldquo;Books are a poor substitute for female companionship, but they are easier to find.&rdquo;
author: Patrick Rothfuss

quote: &ldquo;When I discovered libraries, it was like having Christmas every day.&rdquo;
author: Jean Fritz

quote: &ldquo;I love the way that each book-any book-is its own journey. You open it, and off you go….&rdquo;
author: Sharon Creech

quote: &ldquo;People don\'t realize how a man\'s whole life can be changed by one book.&rdquo;
author: Malcolm X

quote: &ldquo;I guess there are never enough books.&rdquo;
author: John Steinbeck

quote: &ldquo;I still love books. Nothing a computer can do can compare to a book. You can\'t really put a book on the Internet. Three companies have offered to put books by me on the Net, and I said, \'If you can make something that has a nice jacket, nice paper with that nice smell, then we\'ll talk.\' All the computer can give you is a manuscript. People don\'t want to read manuscripts. They want to read books. Books smell good. They look good. You can press it to your bosom. You can carry it in your pocket.&rdquo;
author: Ray Bradbury

quote: &ldquo;There is no reason why the same man should like the same books at eighteen and at forty-eight&rdquo;
author: Ezra Pound

quote: &ldquo;The odd thing about people who had many books was how they always wanted more.&rdquo;
author: Patricia A. McKillip

quote: &ldquo;Fools have a habit of believing that everything written by a famous author is admirable. For my part I read only to please myself and like only what suits my taste.&rdquo;
author: Voltaire

quote: &ldquo;A good novel tells us the truth about its hero; but a bad novel tells us the truth about its author.&rdquo;
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: &ldquo;Without words, without writing and without books there would be no history, there could be no concept of humanity.&rdquo;
author: Hermann Hesse

quote: &ldquo;Stephenie Meyer: Her vampires are sparkly, which I think we can all agree is wrong.&rdquo;
author: Christopher Moore

quote: &ldquo;Despite the enormous quantity of books, how few people read! And if one reads profitably, one would realize how much stupid stuff the vulgar herd is content to swallow every day.&rdquo;
author: Voltaire

quote: &ldquo;I love books. I like that the moment you open one and sink into it you can escape from the world, into a story that\'s way more interesting that yours will ever be.&rdquo;
author: Elizabeth Scott

quote: &ldquo;I think we ought to read only the kind of books that wound and stab us.&rdquo;
author: Franz Kafka

quote: &ldquo;In books I have traveled, not only to other worlds, but into my own.&rdquo;
author: Anna Quindlen

quote: &ldquo;The world was hers for the reading.&rdquo;
author: The world was hers for the reading.

quote: &ldquo;Many a book is like a key to unknown chambers within the castle of one\'s own self.&rdquo;
author: Franz Kafka

quote: &ldquo;Books say: She did this because. Life says: She did this. Books are where things are explained to you; life is where things aren\'t. I\'m not surprised some people prefer books.&rdquo;
author: Julian Barnes

quote: &ldquo;The best moments in reading are when you come across something – a thought, a feeling, a way of looking at things – which you had thought special and particular to you. Now here it is, set down by someone else, a person you have never met, someone even who is long dead. And it is as if a hand has come out and taken yours.&rdquo;
author: Alan Bennett

quote: &ldquo;I cannot sleep unless I am surrounded by books.&rdquo;
author: Jorge Luis Borges

quote: &ldquo;Crying is all right in its way while it lasts. But you have to stop sooner or later, and then you still have to decide what to do.&rdquo;
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: &ldquo;She read books as one would breathe air, to fill up and live.&rdquo;
author: Annie Dillard

quote: &ldquo;From the moment I picked up your book until I put it down, I was convulsed with laughter. Some day I intend reading it.&rdquo;
author: Groucho Marx

quote: &ldquo;The best books... are those that tell you what you know already.&rdquo;
author: George Orwell

quote: &ldquo;I had already found that it was not good to be alone, and so made companionship with what there was around me, sometimes with the universe and sometimes with my own insignificant self; but my books were always my friends, let fail all else.&rdquo;
author: Joshua Slocum

quote: &ldquo;There are books of which the backs and covers are by far the best parts.&rdquo;
author: Charles Dickens

quote: &ldquo;Science and religion are not at odds. Science is simply too young to understand.&rdquo;
author: Dan Brown

quote: &ldquo;My Best Friend is a person who will give me a book I have not read.&rdquo;
author: Abraham Lincoln

quote: &ldquo;The library is inhabited by spirits that come out of the pages at night.&rdquo;
author: Isabel Allende

quote: &ldquo;A good book is an event in my life.&rdquo;
author: Stendhal

quote: &ldquo;In a way, it\'s nice to know that there are Greek gods out there, because you have somebody to blame when things go wrong. For instance, when you\'re walking away from a bus that\'s just been attacked by monster hags and blown up by lightning, and it\'s raining on top of everything else, most people might think that\'s just really bad luck; when you\'re a half-blood, you understand that some devine force is really trying to mess up your day.&rdquo;
author: Rick Riordan

quote: &ldquo;Still round the corner there may wait<br /> A new road or a secret gate<br />And though I oft have passed them by<br /> A day will come at last when I<br />Shall take the hidden paths that run<br /> West of the Moon, East of the Sun.&rdquo;
author: J.R.R. Tolkien

quote: &ldquo;A half-read book is a half-finished love affair.&rdquo;
author: David Mitchell

quote: &ldquo;What she was finding also was how one book led to another, doors kept opening wherever she turned and the days weren\'t long enough for the reading she wanted to do.&rdquo;
author: Alan Bennett

quote: &ldquo;If you would tell me the heart of a man, tell me not what he reads, but what he rereads.&rdquo;
author: François Mauriac

quote: &ldquo;It is a good rule after reading a new book, never to allow yourself another new one till you have read an old one in between.&rdquo;
author: C.S. Lewis

quote: &ldquo;Books are not made to be believed, but to be subjected to inquiry. When we consider a book, we mustn\'t ask ourselves what it says but what it means...&rdquo;
author: Umberto Eco

quote: &ldquo;A book lying idle on a shelf is wasted ammunition.&rdquo;
author: Henry Miller

quote: &ldquo;A house without books is like a room without windows.&rdquo;
author: Horace Mann

quote: &ldquo;A childhood without books – that would be no childhood. That would be like being shut out from the enchanted place where you can go and find the rarest kind of joy.&rdquo;
author: Astrid Lindgren

quote: &ldquo;When I was about eight, I decided that the most wonderful thing, next to a human being, was a book.&rdquo;
author: Margaret Walker

quote: &ldquo;I love books, by the way, way more than movies. Movies tell you what to think. A good book lets you choose a few thoughts for yourself. Movies show you the pink house. A good book tells you there\'s a pink house and lets you paint some of the finishing touches, maybe choose the roof style,park your own car out front. My imagination has always topped anything a movie could come up with. Case in point, those darned Harry Potter movies. That was so not what that part-Veela-chick, Fleur Delacour, looked like.&rdquo;
author: Karen Marie Moning

quote: &ldquo;My library is an archive of longings.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;Have you really read all those books in your room?”<br /><br />Alaska laughing- \"Oh God no. I\'ve maybe read a third of ‘em. But I\'m going to read them all. I call it my Life\'s Library. Every summer since I was little, I\'ve gone to garage sales and bought all the books that looked interesting. So I always have something to read.&rdquo;
author: John Green

quote: &ldquo;When you handle books all day long, every new one is a friend and a temptation.&rdquo;
author: Elizabeth Kostova

quote: &ldquo;She should have done science, not spent all her time with her head in novels. Novels gave you a completely false idea about life, they told lies and they implied there were endings when in reality there were no endings, everything just went on and on and on.&rdquo;
author: Kate Atkinson

quote: &ldquo;[Public] libraries should be open to all-except the censor.<br /><br /><i>[Response to questionnaire in Saturday Review, October 29 1960]</i>&rdquo;
author: John F. Kennedy

quote: &ldquo;And books, they offer one hope -- that a whole universe might open up from between the covers, and falling into that universe, one is saved.&rdquo;
author: Anne Rice

quote: &ldquo;Some books leave us free and some books make us free.&rdquo;
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: &ldquo;One day I would have all the books in the world, shelves and shelves of them. I would live my life in a tower of books. I would read all day long and eat peaches. And if any young knights in armor dared to come calling on their white chargers and plead with me to let down my hair, I would pelt them with peach pits until they went home.&rdquo;
author: Jacqueline Kelly

quote: &ldquo;I love everything that is old; old friends, old times, old manners, old books, old wines.&rdquo;
author: Oliver Goldsmith

quote: &ldquo;I believe that today more than ever a book should be sought after even if it has only one great page in it. We must search for fragments, splinters, toenails, anything that has ore in it, anything that is capable of resuscitating the body and the soul.&rdquo;
author: Henry Miller

quote: &ldquo;I clung to books and words because, unlike people, they\'d never abandon me.&rdquo;
author: Ruta Sepetys

quote: &ldquo;What kind of life can you have in a house without books?&rdquo;
author: Sherman Alexie

quote: &ldquo;I leapt eagerly into books. The characters\' lives were so much more interesting than the lonely heartbeat of my own.&rdquo;
author: Ruta Sepetys

quote: &ldquo;I can imagine no greater bliss than to lie about, reading novels all day.&rdquo;
author: Julia Quinn

quote: &ldquo;When you buy a book at a reasonable price, you buy a new perspective on life, and such a new perspective is priceless because it can open many doors previously closed to you!&rdquo;
author: Mehmet Murat ildan

quote: &ldquo;How I long to feel the weight of a book in my hand. How I long to turn a page, and pass through the print as you\'d pass through a door, into that world of wise and lofty spirits, of strange animals, of noble deeds and faraway cities. If only I could crawl into a book and stay there for the rest of my life.&rdquo;
author: Catherine Jinks

quote: &ldquo;It is a great pity to read a book too soon in life.&rdquo;
author: Winston Churchill

quote: &ldquo;A house without books is like a room without windows. No man has a right to bring up his children without surrounding them with books, if he has the means to buy them. It is a wrong to his family. He cheats them! Children learn to read by being in the presence of books. The love of knowledge comes with reading and grows upon it.&rdquo;
author: Horace Mann

quote: &ldquo;Experience is the best teacher.&rdquo;
author: Penelope Douglas

quote: &ldquo;Bücher sind Bäume, die träumen.&rdquo;
author: Matt Haig

quote: &ldquo;When you re-read a classic you do not see in the book more than you did before. You see more in you than there was before.&rdquo;
author: Clifton Fadiman

quote: &ldquo;Tom lived by the sea. In a small blue house that was from another time. It was squeaky and drafty and held one of my favorite places in the entire world: a big old chair by a front window and a fireplace, from which could be seen a view of the North Sea while one lounged, under a quilt preferably, and read book after book.&rdquo;
author: Paige Shelton

quote: &ldquo;There is something wonderful about a book. We can pick it up. We can heft it. We can read it. We can set it down. We can think of what we have read. It does something for us. We can share great minds, great actions, and great undertakings in the pages of a book.&rdquo;
author: Gordon B. Hinckley

quote: &ldquo;Wouldn\'t you like to have comrades?\' But she would not like that. She wanted only to rest and to read her old, rain-swollen books, turning the pages carefully, so carefully.&rdquo;
author: Catherynne M. Valente

quote: &ldquo;I wanted to crawl in between those black lines of print, the way you crawl through a fence, and go to sleep under that beautiful big green fig-tree.&rdquo;
author: Sylvia Plath

quote: &ldquo;Read much &rdquo;
author: Mohammed Zaki Ansari

quote: &ldquo;Literature is my Utopia. Here I am not disenfranchised. No barrier of the senses shuts me out from the sweet, gracious discourses of my book friends. They talk to me without embarrassment or awkwardness.&rdquo;
author: Helen Keller

quote: &ldquo;Read much, surfing less, traveling more, traveling is the only thing which gives us a real experience of the beauty of different cultures of the world.and gives us the sense to understand different peoples societies and their values<br />Don\'t let social sites control your life, but keep everything under your control especially social sites. This is a real fake world which exists in our real world&rdquo;
author: Mohammed Zaki Ansari

quote: &ldquo;Life was not easy, nor was it happy, but she did not expect life to be easy, and, if it was not happy, that was woman\'s lot. It was a man\'s world, and she accepted it as such. The man owned the property, and the woman managed it. The man took credit for the management, and the woman praised his cleverness. The man roared like a bull when a splinter was in his finger, and the woman muffled the moans of childbirth, lest she disturb him. Men were rough of speech and often drunk. Women ignored the lapses of speech and put the drunkards to bed without bitter words. Men were rude and outspoken, women were always kind, gracious and forgiving.&rdquo;
author: Margaret Mitchell

quote: &ldquo;She\'d always been a little excitable, a little more passionate about books than your average person, but she was supposed to be -- she was a librarian, after all.&rdquo;
author: Sarah Beth Durst

quote: &ldquo;As soon as I saw the bookshelves through the store windows, I felt lighter. Just thinking about the smell inside. Paper, compressed nature, and hands making words, a must of knowing and magic. Periods. Commas. Digressions. Analogies. The beauty of everyday thought turned poetry. It was all there, and I was hit with a little sliver of peace in the chaos of my brain.&rdquo;
author: Dave Connis

quote: &ldquo;Censorship is the child of fear and the father of ignorance.&rdquo;
author: Laurie Halse Anderson

quote: &ldquo;The contents of someone\'s bookcase are part of their history, like an ancestral portrait.&rdquo;
author: Umberto Eco

quote: &ldquo;I hate when people ask what a book is about. People who read for plot, people who suck out the story like the cream filling in an Oreo, should stick to comic strips and soap operas. . . . Every book worth a damn is about emotions and love and death and pain. It\'s about words. It\'s about a man dealing with life. Okay?&rdquo;
author: J.R. Moehringer

quote: &ldquo;What we do, before and after we read, is our choice. And that choice is freedom.&rdquo;
author: Dave Connis

quote: &ldquo;Books are like imprisoned souls till someone takes them down from a shelf and frees them.&rdquo;
author: Samuel Butler

quote: &ldquo;Books were a reminder that the whole world wasn\'t a bleak tapestry of violence, and while she might never see anything beautiful again, at least she could read about kinder things. It was easier to breathe between the pages of a book.&rdquo;
author: Jennifer Gruenke

quote: &ldquo;The long term health problems that high altitude exposures cause are far more wide ranging than what the current generation of books document.&rdquo;
author: Steven Magee

quote: &ldquo;The shelf was filled with books that were hard to read, that could devastate and remake one\'s soul, and that, when they were finished, had a kick like a mule.&rdquo;
author: Mark Helprin

quote: &ldquo;Books can truly change our lives: the lives of those who read them, the lives of those who write them. Readers and writers alike discover things they never knew about the world and about themselves.&rdquo;
author: Lloyd Alexander

quote: &ldquo;I wanted to live among books.&rdquo;
author: Alberto Manguel

quote: &ldquo;I\'ve been doing this for 50 years now and instead of retiring I\'m busier than ever, though perhaps not as fast at getting things done. It\'s all terrifically interesting and very satisfying.&rdquo;
author: Lynley Dodd

quote: &ldquo;I only want power so I can get books.&rdquo;
author: Eliezer Yudkowsky

quote: &ldquo;For the past two years, I had coasted along these waters and each year ended the same. With me returning alone.&rdquo;
author: Sarah Stein

quote: &ldquo;A stereotype becomes a stereotype when a significant percentage of the population appears to conform to it.&rdquo;
author: Kelley Armstrong

quote: &ldquo;Was I a whore? Hell, no. I was a typical woman who was sexually in tune with her body, one who enjoyed everything about sex and exploring the human body.\'<br /><br />An Unforgettable Summer featured in Summer Romances&rdquo;
author: Sarah Stein

quote: &ldquo;What is the quality you most like in a man? <br />The ability to return books.&rdquo;
author: David Bowie

quote: &ldquo;I LEAVE<br />poetry<br />IN<br />LIBRARY<br />BOOKS.&rdquo;
author: Frank Warren

quote: &ldquo;Books open new worlds to me.&rdquo;
author: Aya Ling

quote: &ldquo;Books are more precious than jewels. She truly believed this. What did a diamond bring you? A momentary flash of brilliance. A diamond scintillated for second; a book could scintillate forever.&rdquo;
author: Veronica Henry

quote: &ldquo;The complexities of adult life get in the way of the truth.&rdquo;
author: Mortimer J. Adler

quote: &ldquo;Good books are for consideration after, too.&rdquo;
author: Stephen King

quote: &ldquo;<i>What are you reading?</i> isn\'t a simple question when asked with genuine curiosity; it\'s really a way of asking, <i>Who are you now and who are you becoming?</i>&rdquo;
author: Will Schwalbe

quote: &ldquo;All memory is individual, unreproducible - it dies with each person. What is called collective memory is not a remembering but a stipulating: that this is important, and this is the story about how it happened, with the pictures that lock the story in our minds.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;There are treasures in books that all the money in the world cannot buy, but the poorest laborer can have for nothing.&rdquo;
author: Robert G. Ingersoll

quote: &ldquo;Between ourselves, there is no such thing, abstractly, as a \'good\' book. A book is \'good\' only when it meets some human hunger or refutes some human error. &rdquo;
author: Christopher  Morley

quote: &ldquo;There is a great deal of difference between an eager man who wants to read a book, and a tired man who wants a book to read.&rdquo;
author: G.K. Chesterton

quote: &ldquo;I look at the books on my library shelves. They certainly seem dormant. But what if the characters are quietly rearranging themselves? What if Emma Woodhouse doesn\'t learn from her mistakes? What if Tom Jones descends into a sodden life of poaching and outlawry? What if Eve resists Satan, remembering God\'s injunction and Adam\'s loving advice? I imagine all the characters bustling to get back into their places as they feel me taking the book down from the shelf. \"Hurry,” they say, \"he\'ll expect to find us exactly where he left us, never mind how much his life has changed in the meantime.&rdquo;
author: Verlyn Klinkenborg

quote: &ldquo;She had lolled about for three years at Girton with the kind of books she could equally have read at home--Jane Austen, Dickens, Conrad, all in the library downstairs, in complete sets. How had that pursuit, reading the novels that others took as their leisure, let her think she was superior to anyone else?&rdquo;
author: Ian McEwan

quote: &ldquo;A book is never a masterpiece: it becomes one.&rdquo;
author: Carl Sandburg

quote: &ldquo;The difference between a novelist and someone who tinkers around with writing is this: novelists finish their books.&rdquo;
author: Nancy Etchemendy

quote: &ldquo;A book unwritten is a delightful universe of infinite possibilities. Set down one word, however, and it immediately becomes earthbound. Set down one sentence and it\'s halfway to being just like every other bloody book that\'s ever been written.&rdquo;
author: Robert   Harris

quote: &ldquo;When you\'re in my arms, I know you\'re mine. But your feet are so swift, so swift, they carry you as lightly as wings, I never know where, too fast, too fast away from me.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Perhaps they were looking for passion; perhaps they delved into this book as into a mysterious parcel - a gift box at the bottom of which, hidden in layers of rustling tissue paper, lay something they\'d always longed for but couldn\'t ever grasp.&rdquo;
author: Margaret Atwood

quote: &ldquo;Love the great narcotic was the revealer in the alchemist\'s bottle rendering visible the most untraceable substances. <br />Love the great narcotic was the agent provocateur exposing all the secret selves to daylight.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Collect books, even if you don\'t plan on reading them right away. Filmmaker John Waters has said, \"Nothing is more important than an unread library.&rdquo;
author: Austin Kleon

quote: &ldquo;Remember the good hours when the words are flowing well. And never mind the bad hours; there is no life without them.&rdquo;
author: Herman Wouk

quote: &ldquo;Literature simply becomes richer after you\'ve been fired, rejected, stranded, or had to change a few midnight diapers.&rdquo;
author: Christian Bauman

quote: &ldquo;The summer passed quietly. I busied myself as best I could, reading a good deal.&rdquo;
author: Michael Cox

quote: &ldquo;Just aiming a speely input device, or a Farspark chambre, or whatever you call it... a speelycaptor... at something doesn\'t collect what is meaningful to me. I need someone to gather it in with all their senses, mix it round in their head, and make it over into words.&rdquo;
author: Neal Stephenson

quote: &ldquo;No one stepping for the first time into a room made of books can know instinctively how to behave, what is expected, what is promised, what is allowed. One may be overcome by horror--at the cluster or the vastness, the stillness, the mocking reminder of everything one doesn\'t know, the surveillance--and some of that overwhelming feeling may cling on, even after the rituals and conventions are learned, the geography mapped, and the natives found friendly.&rdquo;
author: Alberto Manguel

quote: &ldquo;Fire is a speed reader, which is why the ignorant burn books: fire races through pages, takes care of all the knowledge, and never bores you with a summary.&rdquo;
author: Elizabeth McCracken

quote: &ldquo;Lanzarme con otro libro es tan grave como enamorarme, un impulso alocado que exige dedicación fanática. Con cada uno, como ante un nuevo amor, me pregunto si me alcanzarán las fuerzas para escribirlo y si acaso semejante proyecto vale la pena: hay demasiadas páginas inútiles y demasiados amoríos frustrados.&rdquo;
author: Isabel Allende

quote: &ldquo;[Books] were devices as crassly practical for storing or transmitting language, as the latest Silicon Valley miracles. But by accident, not by cunning calculation, books, because of their weight and texture, and because of their sweetly token resistance to manipulation, involve our hands and eyes, and then our mind and souls, in a spiritual adventure.&rdquo;
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr.

quote: &ldquo;All good things are powerful stimulants to life, even a good book written against life.&rdquo;
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: &ldquo;It feels to me as thought I\'ve become the character in it, and the character\'s life ends when the books does. I suppose there are times I\'m glad too. Then the ending is like coming out of a bad dream, and I feel all light and free, reborn. I sometimes wonder whether writers really know what they\'re doing to us readers. [...] I don\'t read much anymore [...] maybe for that reason. Because I didn\'t want books to have me in their power. It\'s like poison. I imagined I\'d become immune. But you never become immune. On the contrary.&rdquo;
author: Peter Stamm

quote: &ldquo;Do you love tragedies and everything that breaks the heart?&rdquo;
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: &ldquo;I doubt I was much of a storyteller, but I would have put that smile in my book. On page 104, right next to the image of the Ward. I would have written it on my heart. I would have proofread it a thousand times under a thousand moons until a thousand tears thoroughly rationalized what it meant to me. Each time for when I\'d met the darkness, and then succumbed. The smile read \"you can\'t break me\'”-bold and in italics.&rdquo;
author: Nadège Richards

quote: &ldquo;His books commingled democratically, united under the all-inclusive flag of Literature. Some were vertical, some horizontal, and some actually placed behind others. Mine were balkanized by nationality and subject matter.&rdquo;
author: Anne Fadiman

quote: &ldquo;Books have long been instruments of the divinatory arts. &rdquo;
author: Alberto Manguel

quote: &ldquo;Is there an antidote to the perennial seductiveness of war? And is this a question a woman is more likely to pose than a man? (Probably yes.)&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;There\'s nothing so heavy as books, sir--unless it\'s bricks.&rdquo;
author: Graham Greene

quote: &ldquo;Then it is not uncommon for a man to become lost in a single letter, or hear a voice rise up from the silent page.&rdquo;
author: Howard Schwartz

quote: &ldquo;It must be that people who read go on more macrocosmic and microcosmic trips – biblical god trips, the Tibetan Book of the Dead, Ulysses, Finnegan\'s Wake trips. Non-readers, what do they get? (They get the munchies.)&rdquo;
author: Maxine Hong Kingston

quote: &ldquo;I only wrote prose before I met you. <br />My musings were superfluous and serious as well. <br />But now the words dance with me. <br />I sing with them <br />and we create poetry.&rdquo;
author: Kamand Kojouri

quote: &ldquo;There are two kinds of books in the world--the boring kind they make you read in school and the interesting kind that they won\'t let you read in school because then they would have to talk about real stuff like sex and divorce and is there a God and if there isn\'t then what happens when you die, and how come the history books have so many lies in them.&rdquo;
author: LouAnne Johnson

quote: &ldquo;As with companions so with books. We may choose those which will make us better, more intelligent, more appreciative of the good and the beautiful in the world, or we may choose the trashy, the vulgar, the obscene, which will make us feel as though we\'ve been \'wallowing in the mire.&rdquo;
author: David O. McKay

quote: &ldquo;I knew books could see people around them, they ground their tiny teeth, tried to rattle like windows, stories to tell.&rdquo;
author: Steve Aylett

quote: &ldquo;He says he knows someone isn\'t from the same race as he when that person looks at his library and asks, \'Have you read all of these?\' A true book lover knows that, no, he hasn\'t read them all. It\'s about the process, it\'s about when the right reference comes up, you have the right book to go to; it\'s about never being without something to occupy your eyes and mind.&rdquo;
author: Jamie S. Rich

quote: &ldquo;I found it hard to think of leaving my books. They had been my elevators out of the midden, and to whom could I entrust such close friends?&rdquo;
author: Maya Angelou

quote: &ldquo;Most books are so well written they barely have any effect on the reader\'s senses&rdquo;
author: Steve Aylett

quote: &ldquo;We have evolved a new cosmogony of literature, Boris and I. It is to be a new Bible - The Last Book. All those who have anything to say will say it here - anonymously. We will exhaust the age. After us not another book - not for a generation, at least. Heretofore we had been digging in the dark, with nothing but instinct to guide us. Now we shall have a vessel in which to pour the vital fluid, a bomb which, when we throw it, will set off the world. We shall put into it enough to give the writers of tomorrow their plots, their dramas, their poems, their myths, their sciences. The world will be able to feed on it for a thousand years to come. It is colossal in its pretentiousness. The thought of it almost shatters us.&rdquo;
author: Henry Miller

quote: &ldquo;....her life would be a giddy crossword, working down from some clues and across from others.&rdquo;
author: Leif Enger

quote: &ldquo;You can\'t keep living without breathing; don\'t keep living without reading!&rdquo;
author: Goodreads on Facebook

quote: &ldquo;Books were her salvation. As a child, she\'d had a shelf of childhood favorites that she loved enough to read over and over again. But after, during the hospital stay and the long voyage and the cold days in Idlewild\'s dreary hallways, books became more than mere stories. They were her lifeline, the pages as essential to her as breathing.&rdquo;
author: Simone St. James

quote: &ldquo;But after all we are not children, not illiterate juvenile delinquents, not English public school boys who after a night of homosexual romps have to endure the paradox of reading the Ancients in expurgated versions.&rdquo;
author: Vladimir Nabokov

quote: &ldquo;Bookshop Customer: \'Who wrote the bible?\'<br />Customer\'s friend: \'Jesus.&rdquo;
author: Jen Campbell

quote: &ldquo;Wherever they went the Irish brought with them their books, many unseen in Europe for centuries and tied to their waists as signs of triumph, just as Irish heroes had once tied to their waists their enemies\' heads. Where they went they brought their love of learning and their skills in bookmaking. In the bays and valleys of their exile, they reestablished literacy and breathed new life into the exhausted literary culture of Europe.<br />And that is how the Irish saved civilization.&rdquo;
author: Thomas Cahill

quote: &ldquo;The lack of power to take joy in outdoor nature is as real a misfortune as the lack of power to take joy in books&rdquo;
author: Theodore Roosevelt

quote: &ldquo;And I came to understand, in a way I never had before, that books are truly the stuff of miracles. I even dared to dream that someday, somehow, I might surround myself with books from many times and many tongues...&rdquo;
author: T.A. Barron

quote: &ldquo;Once you\'ve read too many trashy best-sellers, you begin to look for something with substance, something that attempts to define the universe.&rdquo;
author: Jessica Zafra

quote: &ldquo;Being ill when you are a child or growing up is such an enchanted interlude! The outside world, the world of free time in the yard or the garden or on the street, is only a distant murmmur in the sickroom. Inside, a whole world of characters and stories proliferate out of the books you read. The fever that weakens your perception as it sharpens your imagination turns the sickroom into something new, both familiar and strange; monsters come grinning out of the patterns on the curtains and the carpet, and chairs, tables, bookcases and wardrobes burst out of their normal shapes and become mountains and buildings and ships you can almost touch although they\'re far away. Through the long hours of the night you have the Church clock for company and the rumble of the occasional passing car that throws it\'s headlights across the walls and ceilings. These are hours without sleep, which is not to say they\'re sleepless, because on the contrary, they\'re not about lack of anything, they are rich and full. Desires, memories, fears, passions form labryinths in which we lose and find then lose ourselves again. They are hours where anything is possible, good or bad.&rdquo;
author: Bernhard Schlink

quote: &ldquo;Publication is a marathon, not a sprint. Writing the book is only the start.&rdquo;
author: Jo Linsdell

quote: &ldquo;The more we have known of the really good things, the more insipid the thin lemonade of later literature becomes, sometimes almost to the point of making us sick. Do you know a work of literature written in the last, say, fifteen years that you think has any lasting quality? I don\'t. It is partly idle chatter, partly propaganda, partly self-pitying sentimentality, but there is no insight, no ideas, no clarity, no substance and almost always the language is bad and constrained. On this subject I am quite consciously a laudator temporis acti.&rdquo;
author: Dietrich Bonhoeffer

quote: &ldquo;Inconveniently, books are all the pages in them, not just the ones you choose to read.&rdquo;
author: Don Paterson

quote: &ldquo;Vanity\'s contribution to Fiction in general was an abundance of cheap labour and the occasional blockbuster, which was accepted into Fiction with an apologetic \'gosh, don\'t know how that happened\'.&rdquo;
author: Jasper Fforde

quote: &ldquo;It would actually constitute more than a miracle, he realised. It would take divine intervention plus luck, plus some unknown element of cosmic wizardry.&rdquo;
author: David Baldacci

quote: &ldquo;Books do not per­ish like hu­mankind. Of course we com­mon­ly see them bro­ken in the hab­er­dash­er\'s shop when on­ly a few months be­fore they lay bound on the sta­tion­er\'s stall; these are not true works, but mere trash and new­fan­gle­ness for the vul­gar. There are thou­sands of such gew­gaws and toys which peo­ple have in their cham­bers, or which they keep up­on their shelves, be­liev­ing that they are pre­cious things, when they are the mere pass­ing fol­lies of the pass­ing time and of no more val­ue than pa­pers gath­ered up from some dunghill or raked by chance out of the ken­nel. True books are filled with the pow­er of the un­der­stand­ing which is the in­her­itance of the ages: you may take up a book in time, but you read it in eter­ni­ty.&rdquo;
author: Peter Ackroyd

quote: &ldquo;His reading suggested a man swimming in the sea among the wreckage of his ship, and trying to save his life by greedily clutching first at one spar and then at another.&rdquo;
author: Anton Chekhov

quote: &ldquo;Purple Mike promises to be an intriguing read that will teach anyone who wants to know about the highs and lows of drug addiction. Purple Mike is a legal, natural high. Enjoy reading.&rdquo;
author: Sin Mils

quote: &ldquo;more to be a human being with&rdquo;
author: Gary D. Schmidt

quote: &ldquo;In 1994, the average person spent $79 on books as compared to $56 on recorded music.&rdquo;
author: Richard L. Brandt

quote: &ldquo;If you want to reduce the rats, use the cats! If you want to reduce the fools, use the books!&rdquo;
author: Mehmet Murat ildan

quote: &ldquo;Het was een vergissing vanwege de juf, te denken dat alleen de dingen die in de boeken staan interessant zijn. Ook deze, die er nog niet in staan, zijn merkwaardig.&rdquo;
author: Louis Paul Boon

quote: &ldquo;Cartea a dovedit ce poate, și nu vedem un alt obiect mai bun pe care l-am putea crea pentru aceeași întrebuințare.&rdquo;
author: Umberto Eco

quote: &ldquo;Cultura e un cimitir de cărți și de alte obiecte dispărute pentru vecie.&rdquo;
author: Jean-Claude Carrière

quote: &ldquo;Compassion is an unstable emotion. It needs to be translated into action, or it withers.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;But love, the great narcotic, was the hothouse in which all the selves burst into their fullest bloom...&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Now, his hair is white and he no longer understands anyone\'s need to love, for he has lost everything, not to love, but to his games of love; and when you love as a game, you lose everything, as he lost his home and wife, and now he clings to me, afraid of loss, afraid of solitude.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Perhaps too much value is assigned to memory, not enough to thinking. Remembering is an ethical act, has ethical value in and of itself. Memory is, achingly, the only relation we can have with the dead.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;They had reached a perfect moment of human love. They had created a moment of perfect understanding and accord. This highest moment would now remain as point of comparison to torment them later on when all natural imperfections would disintegrate it.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;The fascination exerted by one human being over another is not what he emits of his personality at the present instant of encounter but a summation of his entire being which gives off this powerful drug capturing the fancy and attachment.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;To set their sufferings alongside the sufferings of another people was to compare them (which hell was worse?), demoting Sarajevo\'s martyrdom to a mere instance.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;I am sure you would not understand if I told you my father is delightfully clear and selfish, tender and lying, formal and incurable. He exhausts all the loves given to him. If I did not leave his house at night to warm myself in Rango\'s burning hands I would die at my task, arid and barren, sapless, while my father monologues about his past, and I yawn yawn yawn...&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Out of worship and out of love he would let no one light the stove for her either, as if he would be the warmth and the fire to dry and warm her feet.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Men from the mountains always dream of the sea, and above all things I love to travel.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;No privacy left. No manners.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;No moment of charm without long roots in the past, no moment of charm is born on bare soil, a careless accident of beauty, but is the sum of great sorrows, growths, and efforts.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;It is a view of suffering, of the pain of others, that is rooted in religious thinking, which links pain to sacrifice, sacrifice to exaltation - a view that could not be more alien to a modern sensibility, which regards suffering as something that is a mistake or an accident or a crime. Something to be fixed. Something to be refused. Something that makes one feel powerless.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;Paul, Paul, this is the claim you never made, the fervor you never showed. You were so cool and light, so elusive, and I never felt you encircling me and claiming possession. Rango is saying all the words I wanted to hear you say. You never came close to me, even while taking me. You took me as men take foreign women in distant countries whose language they cannot speak. You took me in silence and strangeness.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Ali Baba protects the lovers! Gives them the luck of bandits, and no guilt, for love fills certain people and expands them beyond all laws; there is no time, no place for regrets, hesitations, cowardices. Love runs free and reckless, and all the gentle trickeries perpetrated to protect others from its burns-those who are not the lovers but who might be the victims of this love\'s expansion.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;He failed to see that it contained at once all of Djuna\'s wishes which had been denied, and these wishes had flown from all directions to meet at this intersection and to plead once more for understanding.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;These rituals Rango could not sustain, for he could not maintain the effort to arrive on time since his lifelong habit had created the opposite habit: to elude, to avoid, to disappoint every expectation of others, every commitment, every promise, every crystallization.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Up to a point, the weight and seriousness of such photographs survive better in a book, where one can look privately, linger over the pictures, without talking. Still, at some moment the book will be closed. The strong emotion will become a transient one.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;It wasn\'t that time stopped in the library. It was as if it were captured, collected here, and in all libraries -- and not only my time, my life, but all human time as well. In the library, time is dammed up--not just stopped but saved.&rdquo;
author: Susan Orlean

quote: &ldquo;Although I was so big, and so rough in many ways, loved hunting, fighting, horseback riding, I loved the piano above everything else...The mountain man\'s obsession is to get a glimpse of the sea.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;It is felt that there is something morally wrong with the abstract of reality offered by photography; that one has no right to experience the suffering of others at a distance, denuded of its raw power; that we pay too high a human (or moral) price for those hitherto admired qualities of vision - the standing back from the aggressiveness of the world which frees us for observation and for elective attention.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;I loved your breaking down that door, repeated Djuna. Through Rango she had breathed some other realm she had never attained before. She had touched through his act some climate of violence she had never known before.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;One can feel obliged to look at phototgraphs that record great cruelties and crimes. One should feel obliged to think about what it means to look at them, about the capacity actually to assimilate what they show. Not all reactions to these pictures are under the supervision of reason and conscience.&rdquo;
author: Susan Sontag

quote: &ldquo;One bright day in the last week of February, I was walking in the park, enjoying the threefold luxury of solitude, a book, and pleasant weather.&rdquo;
author: Anne Brontë

quote: &ldquo;Art is the whisper of history, heard above the noise of time.&rdquo;
author: Julian Barnes

quote: &ldquo;When you learn to read you will be born again...and you will never be quite so alone again.&rdquo;
author: Rumer Godden

quote: &ldquo;What can I say Rango? What can I do to prove to you that I belong to you?&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;When a book and a head collide and a hollow sound is heard, must it always have come from the book?&rdquo;
author: Georg Christoph Lichtenberg

quote: &ldquo;When a book leaves its author\'s desk it changes. Even before anyone has read it, before eyes other than its creator\'s have looked upon a single phrase, it is irretrievably altered. It has become <em>a book that can be read</em>, that no longer belongs to its maker. It has acquired, in a sense, free will. It will make its journey through the world and there is no longer anything the author can do about it. Even he, as he looks at its sentences, reads them differently now that they can be read by others. They look like different sentences. The book has gone out into the world and the world has remade it.&rdquo;
author: Salman Rushdie

quote: &ldquo;He had appointed her not only guardian angel, but a member of his ideals.&rdquo;
author: Anaïs Nin

quote: &ldquo;Reality doesn\'t always give us the life that we desire, but we can always find what we desire between the pages of books.&rdquo;
author: Adelise M. Cullens
